content.description: Climb slopers to a big jug, then mantle up.
content.location:
It is about 5-10 feet right of the

V0

, maybe 30 feet from the left edge of the boulder.

content.description: Start sitting under the overhang on a large triangle block. Climb left a touch then straight up.
content.location: This is on the obvious overhang, where the boulder first starts to get steep after the easier routes to the left.

content.description: Climb up some good holds just left of the large underhang.
content.location:
This is the next route right of the

V1 Sloper

, 35-45' from the left edge. It is left of the overhang that starts the

V2

.

content.description: This is the first route right of the downclimb. It is likely the easiest route here.
content.location: It is 15' right of the East corner that you downclimb.

content.description:
Start for

Star Crossed Lovers

, and move left into

Romeo

.
content.location:
Use the same start as

SCL

.

content.description: Start seated and just left of the northern prow of the Aircraft Carrier. A few juggy pulls will get you to the crux where good core tension should keep you on from a crimp to a sloper then a pinch and finally a jug. You get bonus points if you cut your feet while grabbing the jug. A couple more easy moves and the mantel, and this one's in the bag.
content.protection: A pad, you might want two. It might be nice for the sit start.

content.description:
Again I am still curious of grade and name of this route.

Start below first bolt climb to a slopey ledge using small crimps and small feet.  This part is super balance oriented. Find small crimps and slopey sidepulls to get to the roof. Figure out your feet, and reach up to some slopers and crimps. High step your feet to some slopey feet, and stand up on to a slabby face. Climb up to the anchors.
content.location: It is the fifth route from the right and the last route before the boulder problems.

content.description:
Again I am still curious of this route's grade and name.

Start below first bolt, and climb crimps, edges, and a pinch on top of a left-leaning, undercling thingy to clip the first three bolts. The holds/crimps get better at the third bolt. After the third bolt, obtain an undercling which is above your head, and reach right for sidepull or crimp that allows you to high step your left foot. Then reach up with your right hand for an amazing, resting, jug flake. The fourth bolt is now about head height out to the left. Reach up to a ledge that has some jugs and sloper jugs on it. This was the crux for me trying to clip and get the rope in the draw. Move left on the ledge, and clip the fourth bolt. Climb past the ledge to slopey feet then to better feet and decent holds to the anchors which are a little right.
content.location: It is the fourth route from the right.

content.description: Start a little left of the first bolt. Clip first bolt from left-facing sidepull. Climb up and a little right through one jug and on to the face which is slabby, so just trust your feet. The feet are pretty decent, some get small. The crux for me was clipping and climbing past the fourth bolt. Use small crimps and dishes to climb up to a visible, left-sloping ledge. If you can clip the fourth bolt from below this ledge, do it. If not, climb a little past the ledge using crimps on and around the ledge to get a good, right-facing sidepull, and clip from here. Then make your way onto this ledge using a high, left hand, pocket-type pinch thing. The pocket is not good until you push with your left leg, then you can reach a right-facing, jug sidepull out to the right past the ledge. The rest of the climb is smooth sailing.
content.location: It is the 3rd route from looker's right.

content.description:
Again I am still wondering about grade and names of these routes.

Start a little left of the first bolt, and use left-facing edges/laybacks to climb right to the first bolt. Once on the slab part of the climb, it's easy going with pretty decent feet. This ends on same anchors as

Route 1

.
content.location: It is the 2nd route from the looker's right.

content.description: I am still wondering what all these routes are rated and named, but here is a photo. If anyone knows these, please email me. Climb up the slab. This is a warm-up and an easy climb for people learning to lead.
content.location: This is on the wall directly behind the Aircraft Carrier Boulder. It is looker's rightmost route, kinda around the corner.

content.description:
Sit start to the left of

Star Crossed Lovers

. This is a short problem with a few powerful moves. It is fun forest climbing.
content.protection: This is probably fine with one pad. It has a good, flat landing.
content.location:
It is left of

Star Crossed Lovers

.

content.description:
Rhythm of the Saints is on the backside of the main boulder, directly across from the "

Cool Arete

." It is steep, powerful, and has a tricky mantle.
content.protection: A couple pads and a spot.
content.location: This is on the back of the Aircraft Carrier Boulder.

content.description:
Stand start crossmatched in the slash left of

ROTS

. Climb hard moves up and left.
content.location:
On the backside of the aircraft carrier this is left of

Rhythm of the Saints

.

content.description:
Do the same start as

Star Crossed Lovers

, but go left from the flake to a clearly chalked up left exit. It is slightly harder that the direct line.

Juliet has a shared sit-start with

Star-Crossed Lovers

, but twist out right to extremely sharp crimps and a big move to the lip. A harder direct start may be possible.
content.protection: 1-2 pads. Get a spotter on the right.

content.description:
The problem sits on the boulder just across from "

Cool Arete

" on the right corner of the face.  SDS with left hand on a good, left-facing sidepull and right hand a small, right-facing crimp.  Slap up right and keep making long moves up good compression style holds till a large crimp in the middle, then toss for the top.  There is cool air coming from below the boulder that keeps the holds crisp.

Hangar is potentially a forgotten boulder problem? A lowball, comp-like, morpho boulder hidden below a bolted route gives you underclings, crimps, slopers, and some weird body positioning. Start deep in the cave on a left hand crimp-rail and right hand pinch block. Move up the overhanging dihedral, and exit to the right. The grade is speculative.... There is a video in the comments.
content.location:
It is located on the same wall as

Cool Arete

but on the opposite side of the wall. If you face the bolted wall directly behind

Rhythm of the Saints

, walk right, and the problem is in the overhanging dihedral just after where the talus field starts.

content.description:
Dem Krusbär ascends a rad, bulbous arete. Sit start with your right hand on a sloper sidepull, your left hand on a crimper on the left side of the arete, and with a low, right heel hook. Fun moves lead up to a rad pinch. Continue up the arete using small left hand crimp. It would be especially classic if it weren't so close to

Dem Apples

, but it is worth doing for the rock quality.
content.protection: It's highball, so plenty of pads are good. I did it with 4, more would be better including a spot. I would recommend dropping a line over to rehearse the top. Although easy, this is not really something to fall from.
content.location:
It is located on the backside of the first boulder you get to while walking to Aircraft Carrier to the left of

Dem Apples

.

content.description:
Sit start on two okay pinches then slap your way up good holds with odd feet and tension and a slightly scary move to an undercling-side pull at about 10 feet. The big jug out left is OFF route. If you go left then trav back into the problem this is not the v8 way it was first done. Once on the left hand undercling you can get your feet up and commit to the tall slab above which has a long move to reach the lip at about 20 feet. I did this problem 8/08 and only recently went back to get the thing on video.

As for grade: it's harder (for me) than the other area problems

Extension

, V8;

Return of the Jedi

, V8;

Romeo

, V8; and

Cool Arete

, V9, but this is bouldering, so V7-V10 is the range depending on your strengths and stature.
content.protection: A spotter, 1 big pad, and 1 thin pad for the sit.
content.location: This boulder problem faces north on the boulder that is under the Aircraft Carrier.  If you are facing Romeo (V8), turn around and look down the hill and you will see Dem Apples (V8/9).

content.description: Sit start to the left of the V3 as you approach The Aircraft Carrier. Start under a small overhang, and climb out on small crimps to a positive topout.

This is the first problem you'll see when hiking to the Aircraft Carrier. It is on a large boulder right below the final hill to the main spot.

I am not sure about FAs or actual names on these. This is very straightforward with a couple long pulls on jugs.

Start down and right on some jugs. Begin by traversing left towards the arete for about 6 to 8 moves.  A couple of hard moves and you will be climbing the arete itself for about 4 moves before reaching a jug. Continue climbing jugs  to the top of the arete.
content.location: Located directly behind and west of the Aircraft Carrier Boulder.
